title: Upgrade
content:
This section describes how to upgrade your environment to version 26.1.

Supported upgrade paths

To bring value to customers more frequently, we’ve shortened the product release cycle from half-yearly to quarterly. Meanwhile, we also want to minimize your maintenance window and service interruptions. Therefore, we've adjusted our release and update strategy as follows:

  • Odd version number releases such as, 25.3 typically contain defect fixing and fewer enhancements.  The upgrade process is simpler than the standard version update process, and is comparable to a patch deployment.
  • Even version number releases such as 25.4 provide more features and enhancements and use the standard version update process. 

The 26.1 release supports the following upgrade paths: 

Supported upgrade path Upgrade process
25.4 (and patches) → 26.1 Normal version upgrade

Version update best practice

As a best practice, test the version update process in a test environment before you apply an update in your production environment. This is to verify that everything is working as expected. The following diagram illustrates the recommended process.

​​
The entire process for applying a version update is as follows.

If you have already set up a test environment of version 25.4 before the upgrade, skip step 1 to use the existing test environment. Additionally, if you have already imported tenants from your production environment to the test environment during the previous upgrade, skip step 2.

  1. Set up a test environment: Install suite version 25.4 to set up your test environment. 
  2. Import all tenants from the production environment to the test environment. You must do this before starting the version update in the test environment; otherwise, your version update test can't reveal some problems that you may meet in the production environment.
  3. Apply the version update in the test environment, and verify that everything is working correctly in the test environment.
  4. After successfully verifying the upgrade on your test environment, apply the version update in the production environment.
  5. (Optional) If there is further feature development completed and verified in the test environment, port the development work from the test environment to the production environment.

Version update process

  • The version update solution works only for deployments that use external databases. You can't upgrade the suite if using the embedded PostgreSQL database.
  • Always check the release notes to learn about known issues with the suite upgrade.

This section describes the upgrade process.

The suite version update process leverages the rolling update capability of Kubernetes. This method minimizes system downtime by updating the suite services in a certain order. It updates only 30%~50% of the pods of a service at a time rather than taking down the entire service.

The version update solution covers the following areas: 

  • Kubernetes configuration
  • Binaries of all components of the suite
  • Content of Service Management

The following diagram shows the steps and flow to complete an upgrade. In this diagram, version N represents your current version of OMT and the suite, and version N+1 represents your target version. 

​​

Backup and restore methods

Before a version update, it's recommended that you back up OMT and the suite so that you can restore the system in case a failure occurs. There are two methods for backup and restore:

  • Using virtual machine (VM) snapshots: use this method if you have the privileges and capability to take VM snapshots. Using this method, you only need to take VM snapshots before the OMT update and suite update, and back up OMT and suite databases. If the OMT update or suite update fails, you only need to revert the VMs to the snapshots taken by using a virtualization tool and restore the databases.
  • Using a backup and restore solution that leverages Velero and cloud-native tools and services: This method enables you to back up and restore Kubernetes configurations by using the open-source tool Velero, while using cloud-native backup/restore services to back up and restore PostgreSQL database and external storage data. See Backup and restore for more.

Use the method of using VM snapshots for on-premises deployments only.
